CHRONPROSE.BIRTHPOSITION: Jean Margaret Wemyss (later ML) was born in Neepawa, Manitoba (the town which later modelled for her fictional Manawaka), her parents' only child.

P.BIRTHPOSITION: She later acquired a younger half-brother.

SHORTPROSE.P: Born on the Canadian prairies to a family of Scottish heritage, with professional skills and culture but very little money, ML grew up with a sense of the heroism of pioneer history and with deep-seated rebelliousness against small-town narrowness of vision. As an adult she was an internationalist, a feminist, and an unorthodox Christian whose imagination also responded to elements in African religions.

ML's mother, Verna (Simpson), kept a Mother's Record of Baby until her daughter's fourth birthday. That was just two days before Verna died, aged thirty-four, of an acute kidney infection. She was a gifted musician and pianist.37, 311

ML's father, the town's solicitor, Robert Harrison Wemyss, was a highly skilled amateur carpenter who built his daughter a shed-sized dolls' house complete with furniture and dishes, as well as a desk for writing. After the death of his first wife, Verna, he married her sister Margaret.38-9
Peggy's Aunt Marg thus became her stepmother, Margaret (Simpson) Wemyss. She brought Peggy up from the time of Verna's death, as well as raising from his birth her own son, Bob.39-40

All her life Peggy called her aunt-stepmother Mum. Margaret Wemyss worked as the town librarian, was an early evangelist for Canadian writing,41 and provided serious and constructive criticism of Peggy's early efforts.40-1

Peggy Wemyss (later ML) attended Viscount Collegiate in Neepawa, where her favourite subject was English literature, taught by Mildred Musgrave, and her favourite activity (in competition with sports, playing the violin, and chairing the debating club) was editing the school newspaper. She left with a Governor General's Gold Medal for her scholastic record, and kept for the rest of her life a poetry anthology from Miss Musgrave's class.34, 43-4, 46

Her adolescence was powerfully marked by the second world war. She lived through the deaths of many boys whom she knew, and tried to enlist in the Women's Royal Canadian Naval Service (which, however, stopped recruiting just too early for her).45-6, 306
She also entertained a youthful passion for a British airman, Derek Armstrong, who turned out, to her grief and chagrin, to be married.45-6

Having been unsuccessful in joining the forces, Peggy Wemyss (later ML) therefore, in 1944, entered United College (now the University of Winnipeg) on a Manitoba Scholarship. Here she extended her literary studies to embrace the Modernists, and again served as assistant editor on a student paper. She graduated in 1947 with an honours BA in English and a prize for poetry.34, 46-7, 53

Having worked on, and written for, university publications as a student, Peggy Wemyss found employment on graduating, first with the Westerner (a Communist paper of whose politics she remained unaware), then for the new Winnipeg Citizen, Canada's only co-operative daily. She wrote reviews, labour news, and a radio column.54

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Margaret Wemyss, a recent graduate, married Jack Laurence, a fellow-student whose subject was engineering. He was also a war veteran, having been a mechanic with the RAF.

SHORTPROSE.P: She was, she writes, in love, seriously and deeply and, for the first time, realistically.53 Jack graduated in 1949.64 They had two children, first a girl, Barbara Jocelyn, who was conceived in Somalia but born in London, UK, on 28 August 1952. Next David was born in Accra, Ghana, on 8 August 1955.138, 150 The couple separated in 1962 and divorced in 1969.

ML's childbirth experiences were not propitious. Her daughter was delivered by forceps (at the Elizabeth Garrett Anderson Maternity Hospital in London, UK) after a 36-hour labour, and the delivery cracked the baby's collar-bone—a not unusual occurrence, ML was assured. The bone healed within ten days. Jocelyn lived through a greater danger at two months, when her smallpox and yellow fever injections, for Africa, were administered too close together and in the wrong order. The baby went into convulsions, while the doctor concerned (who was angry with Laurence for insisting on continuing to breast-feed while her daughter was severely ill in hospital) ascribed the convulsions to either a congenital tendency or else meningitis. Two years later another doctor admitted that the first had been at fault. When Laurence got pregnant in Ghana a pregnancy test falsely registered negative, netting her a diagnosis of neurotic, and after that she had two false labours before managing a swift natural childbirth, assisted by a reassuring black midwife. A white nursing sister spoiled the experience slightly by forcing her to eat while in labour although she said she would throw up, which she duly did.138, 141-2, 146-9

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: ML set sail from Canada with her husband for England, en route for Africa.

SHORTPROSE.P: The next month the two of them set out again for the remote areas of Somaliland (now Somalia) where Jack was to work for the British colonial government—but not until he had made a case for her as a kind of Canadian super-backwoodswoman, a natural exception to the rules and conventions governing the movements of most colonial women.124 In 1952 the Laurences moved on to the Gold Coast (which was moving towards achieving its independence as Ghana). They stayed there until 1957, while Jack supervised the building of the country's vital new port, Tema. After leaving Africa for Canada , Margaret flew back twice for independence celebrations: of Ghana in 1958 and the Somali Republic in 1966. Meanwhile after her husband took work in Pakistan in 1962, she visited him at Calcutta in November 1963.64-5, 66, 67, 68

P.SEPARATION: Jack's departure for Pakistan was nevertheless an emotional separation (putting half the world physically between them though not yet determined on a final break) for reasons which included his unenthusiastic response to the draft of Margaret's first novel, The Stone Angel.174-5
P.DIVORCE: Their divorce, in 1969 (after a holiday together in Italy the year before had failed to heal the rift), was very painful for ML in spite of their years apart.309189-90

SHORTPROSE.P: ML's mother-in-law, Elsie Fry Laurence, was the only member of her family who understood, when she separated from Jack, something of her motivation, which was her writing. Elsie had submitted a novel, Half a Gypsy, for publication when she was nineteen, under the name of Christine Field; it had appeared in 1916.125-6
After her divorce in 1969 ML attempted suicide. She locked herself in a bathroom and took an overdose of tranquillizers which kept her asleep for two days.309
She lived in Vancouver from 1957 to 1962 ( a painful time marked by her stepmother's death and the difficulties between her and her husband which led to their separation).67
At the end of this time she left Canada with her two children to settle for some years in England.

In 1962 ML again set out from Canada (where she had been living in Vancouver) to spend some years in England with her children. She hoped to find a congenial literary community there (while her husband went off to work in Pakistan).68
Another reason for travelling to England was that she hoped to establish a lasting relationship with Barbadian poet and novelist George Lamming, with whom she had an affair.68, 308168
She was also said to have had an affair with an ambassador from an African nation, Jamal, a married man with seven children.109223, 224

ML began her English life in Hampstead (at a flat in Hurst Heath Road), then lived at Elm Cottage in the village of Penn in Buckinghamshire. She rented the cottage at first from her London editor, Alan Maclean. It was a wreck, with inadequate heating, mould on the walls, and cigarette burns left by previous tenants on every mantlepiece. ML and her children took it as a challenge, fixing what they could, and even subletting a room because money was so tight.167-9 Of this cottage she wrote: I live on two-thirds of an English acre which appears to be the maple leaf forever. To put it bluntly, the place is crawling with Canadians.68

She bought the cottage with money from the film option that Joanne Woodward and Paul Newman took on Rachel, Rachel—after great difficulty securing a mortgage, since being either a woman or a writer was suspect, and being both at once was even worse.181

During these years ML made several visits back from England to Canada and also visited, partly for the purpose of writing about them, Italy, Greece, and Egypt. Visits to Scotland were more personal, since they were quests for her heritage and for traces of her ancestors' way of life, but their chief effect was to confirm her sense of being a Canadian raised on myths of a fictional Highland identity.70-6

ML was appointed to a succession of writer-in-residence positions: at the University of Toronto in 1969, at the University of Western Ontario in 1973, and the year after that at Trent University. She returned to Trent as Chancellor in 1981.76
During her University of Toronto year ML bought a cedar cabin beside the Otonabee River near Peterborough, Ontario. She called it the Shack, and came to love it deeply.76-7

Her final home, to which she moved on 1 May 1974, was in Lakefield, Ontario (which as an early settlement had been the home of both Susanna Moodie and Catharine Parr Traill). Here ML bought an old brick house.21078

ML perceived a connection between two forces which she passionately opposed: the political colonialism which exerts dominion under the pretext of guiding backward nations towards independence, and the gender colonialism which denies women autonomous control of their own lives on grounds of their lesser capacity. Her daughter defined the political issues that most concerned her as nuclear disarmament, pollution and the environment, pro-choice abortion legislation.304 She might have added the battle against censorship in which Laurence somewhat reluctantly involved herself after The Diviners was banned by Ontario highschools.213-17
Among her fellow writers ML enjoyed a long and close friendship with Adele Wiseman. She also became a friend of the younger Alice Munro, who championed her in the censorship affair.
ML both smoked and drank heavily throughout her adult life. She was diagnosed with lung cancer in August 1968, and underwent surgery but refused other treatment.315, 318

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: ML, under diagnosis of terminal lung cancer, ended her own life at her home in Lakefield, Ontario.

SHORTPROSE.P: Her biographer James King was open about her cigarette addiction. Newspaper reports of her death attributed it to the cancer rather than to suicide.315(Jan. 6, 1987) p.D1

WORKSCITED.SOURCE: Unless otherwise noted, all information is from the FC.

SHORTPROSE.P: ML was a mid-twentieth-century Canadian who began to publish while resident in Africa, putting her gift at the service of preserving oral folk literature through translation and adaptation. Already a journalist, she next turned her hand to essays, short stories, and travel writing. She is best known for her series of Manawaka novels: explorations of the lives of women from a closely imagined prairie community, whose experience takes in the whole span of her century.

PFIRSTLITERARYACTIVITY.PMATERIALCONDITIONS: As a child and teenager, Margaret Wemyss (later ML) was constantly writing stories and poems.
PFIRSTLITERARYACTIVITY.PINFLUENCESHER: She destroyed most of this writing (of which her aunt/stepmother, Margaret Wemyss, was both an inspiration and a useful critic).
PFIRSTLITERARYACTIVITY.PPERIODICALPUBLICATION: Some of it, however, was published in her highschool newspaper and later in Vox at the United College of Winnipeg and in The Manitoban at the University of Manitoba.

P.PEDITIONS: These juvenilia have been collected and edited by Nora Foster Stovel in two publications from the Juvenilia Press: Embryo Words, 1997, and Colours of Speech, 2000.

TEXTSCOPE.PLACEHOLDER: ML, A Tree for Poverty: Somali Poetry and Prose, 1954

CHRONPROSE.RLANDMARKTEXT: ML published her first book at Nairobi, Kenya: A Tree for Poverty: Somali Poetry and Prose, a volume collecting translations of folk literature composed in a language which was as yet exclusively oral.

P.PMOTIVES: Part of ML's aim was to preserve a body of oral literature that might otherwise have been lost.
P.PAUTHORSHIP: She had two collaborators in her work, a local poet named Musa Gabaal, who provided much of the material but could discuss its finer points only in Somali, and a Polish poet and linguist, Bogumił (Gus) Andrzejewski.
P.PEDITIONS: The last copies of the original edition were bought in bulk by the Peace Corps for volunteers going to work in the Somali Republic. The first Canadian edition was photographically produced in 1970 (with Laurence's preface) and 1993.89, 90-1

SHORTPROSE.P: In a few cases involving words whose implications would be lost in English (like hhagar, meaning the thornbush which is almost the only plant growing visibly in the desert) ML refuses to translate, but plants the Somali word in her English sentence.15 Her volume contains only men's poetry, not women's, since Somali verse genres are gendered and Laurence was told the women were too shy to communicate their poems. She included both songs and gabei or long, alliterative narrative poems. The prose consists mostly of moral tales and trickster tales, whose characters are largely male (apart from female monsters or wicked women), with plenty of incident, humour, magic, and religion.88-105

P.RSELFDESCRIPTION: In her preface to her translations, written sixteen years later, ML said she was no antholopologist and called her own translations amateurish,
P.RRESPONSES: but Mary Renault (an English historical novelist settled in South Africa), in a review of her next book, called Laurence a scholar on the strength of this one. An early and appreciative review came from Adele Wiseman (who did not forget to mention Laurence's collaborators).

RPENALTIES.RSHEINFLUENCED: In 1959 the book was paid a back-handed compliment when John Buchholzer plagiarised from it in a travel book which he published about Somaliland.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: ML's first novel, This Side Jordan (set in Ghana and revolving around two institutions, a mission school and a British-owned textile firm), was published simultaneously in Canada, Britain and the USA.

P.TCHARACTERIZATION: Having done extensive research for the cultural background of her African characters, ML was forced into radical revision by the comments of a publisher's reader; she realised that she had so disliked the British colonists in Ghana that she had made them into caricatures.
P.PEDITIONS: A later edition, 1976, was no. 126 in the New Canadian Library, with an introduction by G. D. Killam.

SHORTPROSE.P: The characters and their setting are shaped by the pressure and speed of historical change, the impact of the new on the old and of the traditional on the new—seemingly even more frenetic in Africa than elsewhere. The central figure, Miranda Kestoe, is a white liberal who gradually learns that she is wrong to imagine that she can build a personal understanding with Africa. The third-person narrative, however, presents two male viewpoints in alternate chapters: those of the Ashanti Ghanaian Nathaniel Amegbe, a teacher of African history who is poised between Christianity and the ancient beliefs of his people, and Miranda's husband, the sexist and racist Johnnie, an accountant working temporarily in Africa. Johnnie is impelled by sexual curiosity towards the Black women he despises both for their race and their gender, until his rape of a virgin prostitute (the brutality of which is sharpened by the genital mutilation which had already been inflicted on her) compells him to some self-recognition.

P.RRECOGNITIONS: This book, in manuscript, won the Beta Sigma Phi first novel award of $1,000.155
P.RRESPONSES: Mary Renault welcomed a first novel of rare excellence.140

CHRONPROSE.TSETTINGPLACE: ML followed her African novel with The Tomorrow-Tamer: Short Stories, set in Ghana.

SHORTPROSE.P: The topics of these ten stories include some that are highly challenging: child prostitution, child marriage, wife-beating. Stovel argues that it is Ghana itself which is the hero of the book, as it moves gradually through the de-colonialising process of Africanization, and as the stories progress from the narrative of a white African, son of a missionary (though suckled by a Black nurse), to a celebration of the market woman Mammi Ama.133, 147-51

P.RSELFDESCRIPTION: One of these stories, The Voices of Adamo, was considered by Laurence to be her best.150

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: ML's travel memoir or spiritual autobiography about her time spent in Somalia was published under the title of The Prophet's Camel Bell.

P.PMATERIALCONDITIONS: ML wrote this about a decade after the experience that it describes, drawing on the voluminous diaries she had kept at the time and taking a break from the composition of her first novel.
P.RSELFDESCRIPTION: After working on it for eight months she was dissatisfied with it, finding it bland, mediocre, and superficial.
P.RDESTRUCTIONOFWORK: She destroyed the diaries after she had used them.
P.PEARNINGS: This was one of the several books she wrote in England, and her English editor, Alan Maclean, helped her through a difficult time with a hundred-pound advance.

PEDITIONS.PPLACEOFPUBLICATION: The book was published in the USA under the title New Wind in a Dry Land.122

SHORTPROSE.P: It is written from a consciously outsider point of view, by an author whose nationality separates her from other white women in colonial Africa, as her race and class separates her from the native Africans. She begins by relating her own innocence and eagerness at the start of her travels, anticipating the sight of marvels, and portraying this naive self with irony: There you go rejoicing, as so you should, for anything might happen and you are carrying with you your notebook and camera so you may catch vast and elusive life in a word and a snapshot.131 This attitude contrasts with the material of later pages—drought, death by dehydration, female genital mutilation, and the narrator's gradual, sobering, humbling disillusionment.

P.RRESPONSES: Some of the initial reviews in provincial papers were, said Laurence, good for the laughs, if not exactly flattering.125
Twenty years later George Woodcock called this arguably the best travel book ever written by a Canadian.123-4

TEXTSCOPE.PLACEHOLDER: ML, Long Drums and Cannons: Nigerian dramatists and novelists 1952-1966, 1963

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: ML published a book of criticism, Long Drums and Cannons: Nigerian dramatists and novelists, 1952-1966. It was the first book to appear about Nigerian writing.

SHORTPROSE.P: This book began with a commission from the BBC to write four programmes about Nigerian literature. ML gave herself a crash course in the subject, about which she was very enthusiastic, and expanded her radio work into a book, which she handed to her publisher, Macmillan, on 1 May 1967. It was not reprinted until 2001. She wrote an introduction for it that was never published. The title comes from a poem by Chris Okigbo, who before the book appeared was killed in the Biafran civil war.109, 110, 10, 12185 ML wrote here as a reasonably skilled reader who stood outside the culture.110

Much of what she says about Nigerian writing—its involvement in giving voice to a culture impoverished and devalued by the imposition of colonial standards of judgement, its value for a universal human audience—she and others were later to apply to Canadian writing. The only published book by a woman which she could find to consider was Efuru, 1966, by Florence Nwapa, a hard-hitting novel in which women's plight in traditional Nigerian society is unflinchingly exposed.
ML's book was hailed by reviewers for its pioneering status.

CHRONPROSE.TSETTINGPLACE: ML published The Stone Angel, her first of five books set in or starting out from the fictional prairie town of Manawaka. This, she insisted, though it had elements of her hometown, Neepawa, Manitoba, was not the same.

PINFLUENCESHER.TVOICENARRATION: After completing her first draft ML resisted the advice of her husband to substitute third- for first-person narrative and a straightforward chronological sequence for the vagaries of Hagar's intermittent present consciousness and her remembered past. Jack, in other words, would have preferred a more conventional technique.

SHORTPROSE.P: This book centres on its protagonist-narrator, ninety-year-old Hagar Shipley (née Currie), whom her creator described in a letter to Adele Wiseman as this daft old lady . . . crabby. snobbish. difficult, proud as Lucifer for no reason, a trial to her family, etc. She's also—I forgot to mention—dying.173 The book's working title was Hagar. The stone angel, mentioned in the opening sentence, dominates the cemetery at Manawaka, tall, cold, unseeing, raised by Hagar's father over the grave of her mother and asserting the prominent position of the Currie family in the community. Hagar, named after a great-aunt who then left her money elsewhere, is ultimately named after the biblical servant who was pregnant by the prophet Abraham and was driven out into the wilderness by his wife Sarah. ML's Hagar is a Scots Presbyterian Canadian of the generation of her author's grandparents; her mother died at her birth. Her father valued her for being tougher than his sons, but also bullied and dominated her. She married to offend and escape her father, and then broke the spirit of her rough-diamond husband by trying to tame and polish him. Of her two sons, she favoured the one she perceived as the tougher, but became indirectly responsible for his death in an accident because, disapproving of his girlfriend, she had forbidden him the house. In the present she has escaped from the nursing home she was sent to by her remaining son, and is a wanderer waiting to die. The book, her monologue, ends on an interrupted sentence: And then— Its punctuation clearly implies that this sentence is never finished.308

ML rocketed to success with this first novel. Ethel Wilson, to whom she sent a copy in spring 1964, responded with enthusiastic praise of this great and glorious book.270 It was rated as the best Canadian novel in 1982 and as among the five best in 2002,172 and became a favourite for classroom study. A movie version was released in Canada in 2008.

TSETTINGDATE.TSETTINGPLACE: ML's second Manawaka novel, A Jest of God, was published; it was reissued as Rachel, Rachel by September 1968, under which title it also became a successful film directed by Paul Newman..

SHORTPROSE.P: Rachel Cameron, aged thirty-four and unmarried, is the grade one teacher at the Manawaka school, living with her mother above the funeral home and chapel which once belonged to her now-dead father, the town undertaker. Rachel is trapped in what ML perceives as extended childhood. She is afraid of making an exhibition of herself, afraid of showing her feelings: how much she loves the bright little James, one of the children in her class; how she despises her generous-hearted colleague Calla, who attends a weird religious Tabernacle and wears the same clothes day after day. Rachel secretly mourns her childlessness, resents her demanding mother, and both admires and resents her decisive elder sister Stacey, who has left Manawaka never to return. It is easy to see how close Rachel is coming to the hide-bound conventionality that she dislikes in her mother.

The first upsetting event for Rachel is that she gives in to Calla's persuasion to accompany her (with secret contempt) to the Tabernacle, where she then shocks herself by bursting into unintelligible glossalalia, or speaking in tongues, followed by hysterical crying. Next Calla, having taken her home and tried to comfort her, kisses her on the lips. Next she finds herself in a trivial power struggle with the child James, and feels compelled to assert her authority by hitting him. The major upsetting event is her affair with Nick Kaslik, a contemporary and childhood acquaintance who has moved to Winnipeg but is back visiting his parents for the summer. Nick's Ukrainian heritage is an issue for her snobbish mother. He is her first sexual partner: she wants, needs, loves him; but at the end of the summer he leaves without saying goodbye. She thinks she is pregnant, but it turns out that she has a benign tumour. She makes the first big decision of her life when she arranges to move, with her protesting, emotionally blackmailing mother, to Vancouver to a new job and a new life. The book closes on her conflicting fantasies for her future: becoming eccentric, becoming vague, becoming obsessive, getting married, not getting married. I will quite frequently push the doors marked Pull and pull the ones marked Push. She will make an exhibition of herself. Finally: God's mercy on reluctant jesters. God's grace on fools. God's pity on God.202

P.RRECOGNITIONS: This novel won the Governor General's Award.

RRESPONSES.TCHARACTERIZATION: Many commentators, however, found Rachel self-obsessed and whining. Complaints of her introversion might equally have been made about Hagar, but apparently introversion combined with an unhappiness and unbalance which seemed pecularily female was too much for reviewers to accept.206

TSETTINGPLACE.TSETTINGDATE: ML's novel The Fire-Dwellers was published. It is her third Manawaka novel, and makes a pair with the second, an account of the married sister to follow that of the spinster sister.

P.PMATERIALCONDITIONS: ML had begun writing this novel before A Jest of God, then realised that what she needed was to write two novels, and that the other one must come first.176

SHORTPROSE.P: A reader who has already met Rachel Cameron will know that she envies her married sister Stacey her sex life, her independence, and more especially her motherhood. This novel presents the life of Stacey Cameron MacAindra as she herself experiences it, as unappreciated servitude to four children and an inexpressive husband. A letter which Stacey writes to their mother, full of platitudes, is encountered in the first novel as Mrs Cameron reads it to Rachel, again in this novel as Stacey is writing it. Stacey feels she is juggling with multiple selves, and the fictional technique is correspondingly fractured; the typography signals fantasies and news bulletins (about napalm and the threat of nuclear war) in italics and in capitals.210-11

Stacey's problems, involving the lives of many people, grow and multiply around her. A younger housewife, whose cool elegance she had envied, commits suicide; she throws away her father's gun for fear she might use it to similar effect. The first person she confesses this to is a younger, hippie Italian man with whom she has a brief sexual fling. She worries about the noncommunicativeness of her husband, Mac (not till late in the story does she begin at last to understand the burden he carries of compulsion to be strong because he is male) and about the teenage blossoming of her daughter Katie. She fears for the safety of her two boys (as part of the book's composite climax, Duncan has a narrow escape from drowning), and about the fact that her youngest child, Jen, is still mute at nearly three. Jen's first words (Hi, Mum. Want tea?) make a surprisingly moving moment: then she repeats the question and repeats it, till Stacey wonders: Ye gods. What if she never learns to say anything else?300 This book ends on a brief pause in the rushing world. Duncan has not died, Jen has spoken, Rachel is coming to live nearby with their mother. Stacey, lying awake the night before she turns forty, senses that for the moment the world is still there.

F. M. Watt wrote in a review that this book contains flaws enough to sink half a dozen books by lesser novelists.211 The reviewer for Time magazine hated the book, and moreover, to ML's indignation, wrote that it was autobiographical.209 Respect for it grew slowly, however.

TEXTSCOPE.PLACEHOLDER: ML, A Bird in the House, 1970

TSETTINGDATE.TSETTINGPLACE: ML published A Bird in the House, a collection of linked stories, set in the old Connor house in Manawaka, the Brick House, home of the protagonist's dour pioneer grandfather.

SHORTPROSE.P: The story form gives ML an opportunity for intense compression of meaning. The ten-year-old child Vanessa MacLeod is a professional listener in her extended family, which because of the Depression has folded in on itself. 11 This is the Irish side of the family, her mother's side. Her father's side is Scottish. The opening story, The Sound of the Singing, sets the stage: Grandfather Connor laying down the law in his own pious household, with his doctor son-in-law absent attending a dying man who will not be able to pay. The other family members are Vanessa's mother, pregnant but working as long as she can; her unmarried sister, Aunt Edna, who was working but is now unemployed; the grandmother who must be protected and cossetted; and the ne'er-do-well great-uncle Dan, who turns up singing songs and hoping to borrow money. Vanessa does not understand what milestone has been passed when Grandfather Connor turns his brother out of the house (as he has often threatened to do) and Grandmother unites the others to reverse his action.

The last story in the series teems with events: because Vanessa's father has died, she and her mother and baby brother have given up their own house. They now live all the time with Grandfather and Grandmother Connor. Aunt Edna succeeds at last in getting away, marrying a man who unexpectedly turns out able to stand up to Grandfather. When Vanessa gets to dating, Grandfather taunts her that her boyfriend is probably married. She cannot forgive him for this, because it turns out to be true. The sequence ends many years later when the house is in other hands and, revisiting, Vanessa realises: I had feared and fought the old man, yet he proclaimed himself in my veins.207

Other stories address the central themes of the book in symbolic mode. In The Half-Husky, an adorable puppy given to Vanessa and her brother Robbie turns gradually distrustful and aggressive as the paper boy, Harvey Shinwell, torments him through the fence with a sharp stick and later with worse things. At last Vanessa's mother has the dog destroyed (telling her she has found him a more suitable home on a farm). Later Vanessa learns how Harvey grew up tormented by an unloving aunt who gave him the only home he had. Snubbing the aunt (who was also a person starved of affection), Vanessa is painfully aware that this too, like every link in the chain before it, has been unfair.

CHRONPROSE.PATTITUDES: ML told the poet Al Purdy that she had finished The Diviners, and that her withdrawal symptoms on completing it were worse than usual because she had now brought her sequence of five Manawaka books to a close.

RBESTKNOWNWORK.TSETTINGPLACE: ML published her final novel, The Diviners, whose heroine, Morag Gunn, is another native of Manawaka.

P.PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY: She had cut down her first draft, of nearly 700 pages in typescript, to 578 pages, and intended to cut it by another hundred.

PSUBMISSIONSREJECTIONS.PPLACEOFPUBLICATION: It was, however, accepted by all of her publishers: McClelland and Stewart in Canada, Knopf in the USA, and Macmillan in England.

SHORTPROSE.P: The novel's title comes from the frame fiction surrounding the central tale, that of Morag Gunn, a writer in difficulty with her writing. Morag, hoping to make a new start in the house where she has settled beside the Otonabee River in Ontario, sees the water-diviner (who comes to prospect for the well she proposes to have dug) as a symbol of the writer, calling by magic ritual on the life-giving water which he cannot see. This moment drives her back to seek the sources of her power in the hidden springs of her own life.

Morag's parents died in the flu epidemic that followed the First World War. She is brought up by Manawaka's most marginal couple, the garbage-collector, Christie Logan, and his obese wife, Prin (short for Princess). Her success at school only partly offsets this experience of living as underclass. She shares Christie's intoxication over their joint, mythic or heroic, Scottish Highland heritage. Later, through her long on-again, off-again relationship with the Metis folk-singer Jules (Skinner) Tonnerre (a childhood friend, the closest she ever comes to a continuing lover, the father of her child) she experiences the other marginal positions occupied on the prairies by Native and French-descended people. At university she is taught by Brooke Skelton, an Englishman convinced of his cultural superiority, and on marrying him she realises that he feels superior through his gender, too: a woman, like a territory, can be colonized. Through her personal life Morag experiences the competing national myths of Canada, and as a writer she is constantly spinning myth and empowerment out of her own often raw and painful actuality both past and present. This actuality includes both an abortion and a casual sexual encounter which turns violent and frightening. The novel's unfudged depiction of these episodes provoked its banning from highschool curricula in Ontario public schools. ML, who defined herself as both a moral and a Christian writer, found this episode immensely painful.

P.RRESPONSES: Again one reviewer, this time a woman writing for a Canadian magazine, insisted against Laurence's protests that the novel was entirely autobiographical.208

The Feminist Companion called The Diviners a spacious novel which translates experience into art by various formal devices including the admonitory voice of Catharine Parr Traill, the pioneer author whose superwoman ability to rise above difficulty Morag finds both inspirational and irritating.
Nora Stovel calls the book Laurence's most metafictional and meta-autobiographical novel.263

SHORTPROSE.P: ML formed the intention of concluding her Manawaka cycle with a novel about her terrible experience of being censored, rebuked, and hated for The Diviners. She planned to call it Dance on the Earth. She worked on this novel during 1982 and 1983, but was unable to finish it. Only after that did she compose her memoir of the same title.264, 266

ML published four books for children over a span of ten years: first Jason's Quest, 1970 (illustrated by Staffan Torell), then Six Darn Cows, 1979 (contributed to a series called Kids of Canada, with a prescribed, limited vocabulary), and The Olden Days Coat, also 1979 (dedicated to Tamara Stone, daughter of the writer Adele Wiseman),298 and finally The Christmas Birthday Story, 1980.

P.PMOTIVES: She wrote the last-published first: a Christmas Nativity story written in 1960, for her children's Sunday School at the Unitarian Church in Vancouver, where earnest sceptics wanted the involvement of angels downplayed.
P.PMANUSCRIPTHISTORY: She then lost her copy. Years later she found the story was still being used in the same church, and was offered a copy,
P.PRARITIESFEATURESDECORATIONS: which she then revised for publication with illustrations by Helen Lucas (black and white so that children might colour them in).
P.RRESPONSES: She met with condemnation from the orthodox for saying that Joseph and Mary didn't mind whether their baby turned out to be a boy or a girl. But a prairie Jewish author, Fredelle Maynard, told her that this was the only telling of the Nativity story to put in the hands of a Jewish child.

SHORTPROSE.P: Jason's Quest began when ML and her two children found mole-hills on the lawn at their cottage in England (which she got rid of by means of a mole-catcher).189 In the book the young mole Jason sets out on a dangerous journey to a place called Thither, seeking a cure for a mysterious illness that afflicts the denizens of Molanium—a complaint which turns out to be boredom.

P.TPLOT: In Six Darn Cows the farm children (a girl and a boy) first wish the cows would just get lost and then leave a gate open, so they are doubly responsible when the cows are lost and doubly relieved when they help materially in finding them.

SHORTPROSE.P: The Olden Days Coat, called by Nora Stovel ML's best-loved childrens' book, is also highly characteristic in its fascination with the passage of time. Ten-year-old Sally dresses up in some clothes which belonged to her grandmother when young, and finds herself transported back into the past. There she meets a girl of her own age, who impresses her by being out alone driving two horses in a cutter (a sleigh). After she succeeds in getting back to the present day, she realises that the other girl was no other than her grandmother.297

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: ML collected a volume of nineteen essays already published in periodicals, under the title Heart of a Stranger. She wrote that in collecting them she was surprised to find they were all travel pieces.

SHORTPROSE.P: She writes here of travelling in Scotland, Greece, and Egypt, as well as about the impact of places where she spent longer: sub-Saharan Africa, England, and Canada. She describes both the comic and harrowing incidents involved in travel, and the effect of place and its discoveries on her inner life.

TEXTSCOPE.PLACEHOLDER: ML, Dance on the Earth: A Memoir, 1979

PLASTLITERARYACTIVITY.PAUTHORSHIP: ML's unfinished memoir, Dance On The Earth, was posthumously published, completed by her daughter, Jocelyn Laurence,
PLASTLITERARYACTIVITY.PRARITIESFEATURESDECORATIONS: with a photo by her son, David Laurence.

SHORTPROSE.P: ML had often thought of writing her autobiography. She finished a draft of her memoir in July 1986, the month before she was diagnosed with lung cancer. While recovering from surgery she found herself physically incapable of revising on a typewriter, so her second version was typed from her dictation by Joan Johnstone. This process was finished on 6 October 1968, just three months before Laurence took her own life. Her daughter edited by smoothing and eliminating repetitions, but she also made many short cuts to bring down the overall length. ML dedicated this book to both of her children.314, 318, 325The published work (whose title comes from a modern hymn by Sydney Carter)305-6 includes poems by ML, and letters to Adele Wiseman.

In a foreword ML explains that this is not the entire story of her life, but an examination of matters close to her heart. She considers especially the issue of maternity, its relation to creativity, and the influence on her of her mothers and foremothers. She sometimes said this was a book about four mothers: her birth mother, her adoptive mother, her mother-in-law, and herself as mother to both her children and her writings. For them all she used the metaphor of dance as life and as the handing on of life.303-4, 310

P.RRESPONSES: Reviewers found this book somewhat shadowy and evasive, in the manner of an apologia rather than an objective account.

SHORTPROSE.P: ML kept a journal almost up to the moment of her death. She ended it with a plea to her near & dear ones to forgive and understand her action. My spirit is already in another country, & my body has become a damned nuisance. I have been so fortunate.314
